questions.text: Identify the egg in the image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hymenolepis nana The given image of the egg and lifecycle is that of Hymenolepis nana. nana egg is colourless, almost transparent, oval, 30–50 µm (micrometres) in diameter, and has polar filaments. When shed in stool they are immediately infective and survive up to 10 days in the external environment, they are embryonated and have 6-hooked oncospheres inside the shells. Shell consists of two distinct membranes. On the inner membrane there are two small “knobs” or poles from which 4–8 filaments arise and spread out between the two membranes.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is a dematiaceous fungi The given image shows copper penny bodies. This along with the clinical presentation is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis. It is a dematiaceous fungus . Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue caused by several different dematiaceous fungi (brown pigment-producing), resulting in the formation of slow-growing, warty plaques, cauliflower-like lesions which may ulcerate. The disease generally remains localised, but lymphatic spread may occur

questions.text: A patient presents lesions on the black eschar on the back with chills and high grade fever. The probable cause could be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scrub Typhus Option A is the correct answer Scrub typhus , also known as bush typhus, is a disease caused by a bacteria called Orientia tsutsugamushi . Scrub typhus is spread to people through bites of infected chiggers ( larval mites ). The most common symptoms of scrub typhus include fever, headache, body aches, and sometimes rash. Black eschar is present at the site where larvae bites. DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSIS OF AN ESCHAR

questions.text: Fungus having non-septate hyphae and producing sporangiospores is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phycomycetes Phycomycetes are lower fungi which have non-septate hyphae and form endogenous asexual spores (sporangiospores) contained within sporangia Systematic classification of fungi, based on their sexual spore formation, recognizes 4 classes: Phycomycetes: Non-septate hyphae, produces sporangiospores (asexual spores), oospores and zygospores (sexual spores) Ascomycetes: Septate hyphae, Produces conidia (asexual spores) and ascospores (sexual spores) Basidiomycetes: Septate hyphae, Produces conidia (asexual spores) and basidiospores (sexual spores) Fungi imperfecti: Septate hyphae, Produces conidia (asexual spores) and sexual phase has not been identified.

questions.text: EBV infects B cells through which of the following receptors:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CD21 The Ebstein-Barr virus (EBV) binds to CD21 and acts as a B cell mitogen

Extraedge:

Epstein Barr virus (EBV) is a herpesvirus in which over 90% of the population worldwide has been infected. EBV infection can range from asymptomatic to infectious mononucleosis. Epstein Barr virus (EBV) is a double-stranded DNA virus that infects B lymphocyte cells Pathogenesis Memory B cells (not epithelial cells) are reservoirs for EBV. EBV receptor is CD21 (found on B cell surface) Cellular immunity (NK cells, cytotoxic T cells) is more important than humoral immunity in controlling infection EBV causes productive (lytic) infection of epithelial cells and latent infection in B lymphocytes

questions.text: A boy presented with fever, chills, myalgias, weakness, nausea, vomiting, cough. headache, and malaise following a forest safari. identify the following causative organism from the given image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anaplasma phagocytophilum The given image shows a morula in a granulocyte which is seen in anaplasma . Please note that the patient does not have any rash. Anaplasma phagocytophilum is an obligate gram-negative , intracellular bacterium that causes an acute febrile illness known as anaplasmosis or human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA) Rash is uncommon in anaplasmosis. Some patients infected with E. chaffeensis develop a maculopapular or petechial rash on the trunk and extremities. Ehrlichia chaffeensis is a gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium that is transmitted by hard ticks Clinical presentation of Ehrlichia chaffeensis infection is similar to that of Anaplasma infection. Severe human monocytic ehrlichiosis is characterised by meningoencephalitis, renal failure, respiratory failure, and shock. The treatment of choice for human monocytic ehrlichiosis is Rickettsia rickettsii causes rocky mountain spotted fever and is transmitted by ticks. Rickettsia conorii causes Mediterranean spotted fever and is transmitted by infected ticks and mites.

Highyeild:

Ixodes ticks transmit Anaplasma phagocytophilum Diagnosed by culture, histopathology, PCR, or serology: The presence of intracytoplasmic aggregates of Anaplasma in peripheral blood neutrophils can be diagnostic in 20% to 80% of symptomatic patients. First-line treatment is doxycycline 100 mg orally, twice daily administered for 14 to 21 days Infection by both Anaplasma and Ehrlichia can lead to the formation of rickettsial morulae in leukocytes. However, Anaplasma leads to the formation of morula predominantly in the granulocytes, whereas Ehrlichia predominantly affects the monocytes .
